ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
I learned the basic knowledge about hardware design and the skill to write Verilog language.
I learned the knowledge about cloud FPGAs, especially security problem.
I went in knowing nothing about FPGAs, and by the end I was able to program one and work to solve a genuine research question in the field.

Background on the working of FPGAs.
Background on Hardware design using Verilog.
Basic verification techniques.
Basics of Cloud FPGA infrastructure. 
Existing research work on Cloud FPGA security. 
Potential Research Areas to work on.
FPGA programming in Verilog, thinking about FPGA security issues, detailed manipulation of FPGA operation parameters
I learned a lot about FPGAs in general, there aren't any other classes that talk about them so it was nice exposure.

I learn about Cloud FPGA systems and services. In addition, I learned how to design and program different hardware modules on FPGAs. I learned about the security risks of Cloud FPGA systems as well as the research into multi-tenant implementations of Cloud FPGAs.
I learned about FPGAs and their use in the cloud
Learnt about the state of the art in cloud fpga security and hdl programming in general.

Jakub's course was really insightful.
It helped me learn a lot about cloud fpgas and the final project was also an interesting aspect too.
Go through the basics of the FPGA. The idependent research on a FPGA-related topic is fun!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The course contains very helpful knowledge about hardware and security problems. It is very helpful to students who are interested in FPGA.

I would like to learn more how to actually use the cloud FPGAs like Amazon F1.
The strength of this course was that it taught from the ground up, and the professor and TF were truly excellent educators. I really liked the course design, I dont think there was a weakness in it.

Strengths: The course has a mix of challenging and straightforward assignments, which helps understand how to work with the FPGA and sets an excellent background for the project. All the assignments are assigned and completed by the mid-semester of the term, giving a fair amount of time to work on a course project.

Weakness: Hands-on practice with commercial cloud FPGAs such as AWS was missing. An assignment around that could be given as an extra credit assignment, and it would be a nice challenge.

Very interesting final project as an open ended research problem. We got to read up on a security-related issue, investigate potential approaches to compromise the FPGA, and try out the techniques in the lab. This was a great highlight and let us practice various EE knowledge together (e.g. use signal analysis to make sense of the raw data collected). Professor Jakub's slides are also very well organised and great to read.

It was a good class on cloud FPGAs but since I didn't have a huge background of FPGAs beforehand it took a bit to get familiar with the basic concepts and language. That's less of an issue with this class though, more of an Yale EE major side effect.

The strengths of this course is the availability and support offered by Professor Szefer. One weakness of the course is the lack of information provided on hardware description language. The course can be improved by more time spent on how to implement hardware description language for module design.
We worked on an assigned project throughout the semester. The project was interesting but not completely related to the material taught in class
Awesome class.

The course was great.
I see no improvements other than more practicals.

The FPGA learning framework designed for this course is excellent! There are also quite a lot resources provided for students for preparing their projects.

One thing could be improved is that there can be more assignments on the FPGA security part. The assignments for the second part of the class is a little weak compared to the first part which is very well designed.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes I would recommend this course to other students. The course is very helpful to students who want to learn about hardware design and security.
Yes! To anyone interested in FPGAs, or working on a cool problem.

I strongly recommend this course to every student who is interested in FPGAs. Even though if their expertise is different than in FPGAs, I am pretty sure that they will find a project to fit in which will intersect their expertise with some FPGAs topics.

Yes, for aspiring hardware design engineers this course is highly recommended. The course consists of cutting-edge assignments and projects which will make you ready to work on real-world applications. The course facilitates very well (by providing enough background in the introductory lectures) even the students who do not have a prior hardware development background can learn about cloud FPGA development.

Yes, great way to gain Verilog programming skills which are important for electrical engineering. The pace of the class is also very reasonable, and the final project is doable with enough planning earlier during the semester. Be careful of real-world bugs when working with the FPGAs however, as there will very likely be some unexpected issue that complicates data collection. Still, one of the more exciting EE courses in my opinion.
If they were interested in the material I would recommend it.
I would recommend this course to another student because the course is very interesting and it is a great introduction into Cloud FPGAs.
Yes! Professor Szefer is great and gives clear feedback.
Yes! Working on a novel project and presenting your findings was a very fulfilling part of this class. Professor Szefer is also awesome!
I would recommend this course if you're interested in learning about fpgas.
Yes, I will recommend this course for those who want to learn more about the basics fo FPGA, and want to have a chance to expose themeselfs to the simple FPGA-related research.
